Disease.content:
Please identify the "Disease" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: This flow was measured by using a differential pressure transducer , passed through a polygraph , and from this to a computer with custom software that derived ventilation ( VE ) , tidal volume ( VT ) , inspiratory time ( TI ) , expiratory time ( TE ) , breathing frequency ( f ) , and mean inspiratory flow ( VT / TI ) on a breath - by - breath basis .

Let's think step by step.

1. Measuring the flow: This process is related to medical equipment and techniques, but it does not directly mention any specific disease.

2. Using a differential pressure transducer: This is a medical device used for measuring pressure differences, but it is not a disease.

3. Passed through a polygraph: A polygraph is a medical instrument used to record various physiological responses, but it is not a disease.

4. Computer with custom software: This is a tool used for processing and analyzing data, but it is not a disease.

5. Derived ventilation (VE): Ventilation refers to the process of moving air in and out of the lungs, which can be affected by various respiratory diseases such as asthma, COPD, and pneumonia.

6. Tidal volume (VT): Tidal volume is the amount of air that is inhaled and exhaled during normal breathing. It can be affected by various respiratory diseases such as COPD, asthma, and pneumonia.

7. Inspiratory time (TI): Inspiratory time is the duration of a breath during which air is being inhaled. It can be affected by various respiratory diseases such as COPD, asthma, and neuromuscular disorders.

8. Expiratory time (TE): Expiratory time is the duration of a breath during which air is being exhaled. It can be affected by various respiratory diseases such as COPD, asthma, and cystic fibrosis.

9. Breathing frequency (f): Breathing frequency is the number of breaths taken per minute. It can be affected by various conditions such as hyperventilation, hypoventilation, and respiratory diseases such as asthma and COPD.

10. Mean inspiratory flow: Mean inspiratory flow is the average rate of airflow during inspiration. It can be affected by various respiratory diseases such as asthma, COPD, and cystic fibrosis.

Therefore, the following entities in the paragraph are related to diseases: asthma, COPD, pneumonia, neuromuscular disorders, hyperventilation, and hypoventilation.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Disease.

1. Asthma
2. COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease)
3. Pneumonia
4. Neuromuscular disorders
5. Hyperventilation
6. Hypoventilation.

These are the entities in the paragraph that clearly refer to diseases.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Disease".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Disease |
| --- |
| Asthma |
| COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease) |
| Pneumonia |
| Neuromuscular disorders |
| Hyperventilation |
| Hypoventilation |

Chemical.content:
Please identify the "Chemical" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: This flow was measured by using a differential pressure transducer , passed through a polygraph , and from this to a computer with custom software that derived ventilation ( VE ) , tidal volume ( VT ) , inspiratory time ( TI ) , expiratory time ( TE ) , breathing frequency ( f ) , and mean inspiratory flow ( VT / TI ) on a breath - by - breath basis .

Let's think step by step.

1. Differential pressure transducer: This is an electronic device used to measure the difference in pressure between two points. It does not contain any specific chemical entities.
2. Polygraph: A polygraph is a medical instrument used to record various physiological functions such as blood pressure, heart rate, respiration, etc. It does not contain any specific chemical entities.
3. Computer: A computer is an electronic device used to process information. It does not contain any specific chemical entities.
4. Custom software: Software is a set of instructions that a computer uses to perform specific tasks. It does not contain any specific chemical entities.
5. Ventilation (VE): Ventilation refers to the process of moving air in and out of the lungs. It is a measure of the volume of gas that is moved in and out of the lungs during breathing.
6. Tidal volume (VT): Tidal volume is the amount of air that is inhaled or exhaled during a single breath. It is a measure of the volume of gas that is moved in and out of the lungs during breathing.
7. Inspiratory time (TI): Inspiratory time is the duration of a breath, from the start of inhalation to the start of exhalation. It is a measure of the time it takes for air to flow into the lungs during a breath.
8. Expiratory time (TE): Expiratory time is the duration of a breath, from the start of exhalation to the end of exhalation. It is a measure of the time it takes for air to flow out of the lungs during a breath.
9. Breathing frequency (f): Breathing frequency is the number of breaths taken per minute. It is a measure of the rate at which a person is breathing.
10. Mean inspiratory flow: Mean inspiratory flow is the average rate of airflow during inspiration. It is a measure of the speed at which air is moving into the lungs during a breath.

There are no specific chemical entities mentioned in the paragraph. The paragraph describes the measurement of various respiratory parameters using medical equipment.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Chemical.

1. Tidal volume (VT): Tidal volume is the amount of gas that is moved in and out of the lungs during a breath.

This is the only entity in the paragraph that clearly refers to a chemical substance (air or gas) and its volume. All other entities described in the paragraph are related to measuring and analyzing the flow of this gas during respiration.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Chemical".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Chemical |
| --- |
| Tidal volume (VT) |

Tidal volume (VT) is the amount of gas that is moved in and out of the lungs during a breath.
